description:
When writing new Java (web) applications, teams often have nagging doubts: "Will my application scale?"





  • How many users can my application simultaneously handle?
  • How fast will my controllers dash out those JSON responses?
  • How much memory, CPU, or I/O does my application need? 
  • Where is most time spent in my application?
  • How much money do I need to spend on hosting and what instance types are appropriate for my app?


Surprisingly, there's very little advice out there on how to sensibly approach these questions in a practical way- apart from that deceiving gut feeling that tells you that everything will be fine, by simply auto-scaling your Kubernetes pods into oblivion.

In this #almostnoslides session we're going to use a terminal, an IDE and a couple of other tools to get a deep, practical understanding of the following scaling topics:





  • Throughput: How to reliably find out to how many users your application will scale to
  • Memory & CPU: How much (or how little) memory & CPU your Java app actually needs
  • Latency: How your web app would compare to a Counterstrike game server
  • Servers & Hosting: What the cheapest [cloud] server is able to host
  • And much more


By the end of this talk, you'll have learned all the tools and, more importantly, solid load-testing processes that will hopefully make you never worry about scale again.
title: Why you don't need to worry about scaling your Java webapp
